translated: Then one becomes heedful, for yoga is the origin and end of all.

original: tām īdṛśīṃ tadavasthāṃ yogam iti manyante viyogam eva santam /
analyzed: tām īdṛśīm tad avasthām yogam iti manyante viyogam eva santam
translated: They consider that state to be yoga, which is actually separation.

original: sarvānarthasaṃyogaviyogalakṣaṇā hīyam avasthā yoginaḥ /
analyzed: sarva anartha saṃyoga viyoga lakṣaṇā hi iyam avasthā yoginaḥ
translated: For this state of the yogi is characterized by separation from all undesirable things.

original: etasyāṃ hy avasthāyām avidyādhyāropaṇavarjitasvarūpapratiṣṭha ātmā /
analyzed: etasyām hi avasthāyām avidyā adhyāropaṇa varjita svarūpa pratiṣṭhaḥ ātmā
translated: For in this state, the Self abides in its own nature, free from the superimposition of ignorance.

original: sthirām indrayadhāraṇāṃ sthirām acalām indrayadhāraṇāṃ bāhyāntaḥkaraṇānāṃ dhāraṇam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sthirām indraya dhāraṇām sthirām acalām indraya dhāraṇām bāhya antaḥkaraṇānām dhāraṇam iti arthaḥ
translated: Firm control of the senses means firm, unmoving control of the senses, which means control of the external and internal organs.

original: apramattaḥ pramādavarjitaḥ samādhānaṃ prati nityaṃ yatnavāṃs tadā tasmin kāle /
analyzed: apramattaḥ pramāda varjitaḥ samādhānam prati nityam yatnavān tadā tasmin kāle
translated: At that time, when one is always diligent in concentration, free from negligence, then.

original: yadaiva pravṛttayogo bhavatīti sāmarthyād avagamyate /
analyzed: yadā eva pravṛtta yogaḥ bhavati iti sāmarthyāt avagamyate
translated: It is understood by implication that this is when one has begun yoga.

original: na hi buddhyādiceṣṭābhāve pramādasaṃbhavo 'sti /
analyzed: na hi buddhi ādi ceṣṭā abhāve pramāda saṃbhavaḥ sti
translated: For when there is no activity of the intellect etc., negligence is not possible.

original: tasmāt prāg eva buddhyādiceṣṭoparamād apramādo vidhīyate /
analyzed: tasmāt prāk eva buddhi ādi ceṣṭā uparamāt apramādaḥ vidhīyate
translated: Therefore, even before the cessation of the activity of the intellect etc., non-negligence is enjoined.

original: athavā yadaivendriyāṇāṃ sthirā dhāraṇā /
analyzed: athavā yadā eva indriyāṇām sthirā dhāraṇā
translated: Or, when there is firm control of the senses,

original: tadānīm eva niraṅkuśam apramattatvam ity ato 'bhidhīyate 'pramattas tadā bhavatīti /
analyzed: tadānīm eva niraṅkuśam apramatta tvam iti atas bhidhīyate pramattaḥ tadā bhavati iti
translated: at that very time, one is free from negligence. Therefore, it is said that at that time, one becomes free from negligence.

original: kutaḥ /
analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

original: yogo hi yasmāt prabhavāpyayāv upajanāpāyadharmaka ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: yogaḥ hi yasmāt prabhava apyayau upajana apāya dharmakaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Because yoga has origin and cessation, which means it has the property of increase and decrease.

original: ato 'pāyaparihārāyāpramādaḥ kartavya ity abhiprāyaḥ // // / / //
analyzed: atas pāya parihārāya apramādaḥ kartavyaḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Therefore, in order to avoid cessation, non-negligence should be practiced - this is the intention.

original: naiva vācā na manasā prāptuṃ śakyo na cakṣuṣā /
analyzed: na eva vācā na manasā prāptum śakyaḥ na cakṣuṣā
translated: It cannot be attained by speech or mind, nor by the eye.

original: astīti bruvato 'nyatra kathaṃ tad upalabhyate // // / / //
analyzed: asti iti bruvataḥ nyatra katham tat upalabhyate
translated: How is that known to exist elsewhere, when one says it exists?

original: buddhyādiceṣṭāviṣayaṃ ced brahmedaṃ tad iti viśeṣato gṛhyeta /
analyzed: buddhi ādi ceṣṭā viṣayam ced brahma idam tat iti viśeṣataḥ gṛhyeta
translated: If Brahman were the object of the activity of intellect etc., it would be apprehended specifically as that.

original: buddhyādyuparame ca grahaṇakāraṇābhāvād anupalabhyamānaṃ nāsty eva brahma /
analyzed: buddhi ādi uparame ca grahaṇa kāraṇa abhāvāt anupalabhyamānam na asti eva brahma
translated: And when intellect etc. cease, Brahman, not being apprehended due to the absence of a cause of apprehension, does not exist at all.

original: yad dhi karaṇagocaraṃ tad astīti prasiddhaṃ loke viparītaṃ cāsad iti /
analyzed: yat hi karaṇa gocaram tat asti iti prasiddham loke viparītam ca asat iti
translated: For in the world, it is well known that what is within the range of the means of knowledge exists, and the opposite of that does not exist.🔽Therefore, it is concluded that Brahman is to be known as non-existent, because it is not apprehended, or the yoga is meaningless.

original: ataś cānarthako yogo 'anupalabhyamānatvād vā nāstīty upalabdhavyaṃ brahmety evaṃ prāpta idam ucyate /
analyzed: atas ca anarthakaḥ yogaḥ anupalabhyamāna tvāt vā nā asti iti upalabdhavyam brahma iti evam prāpte idam ucyate
translated: To this, it is said:

original: satyam /
analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

original: naiva vācā na manasā na cakṣuṣā nānyair apīndriyaiḥ prāptuṃ śakyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: na eva vācā na manasā na cakṣuṣā na anyaiḥ api indriyaiḥ prāptum śakyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it cannot be attained by speech, mind, eyes, or any other sense organs.

original: tathāpi sarvaviśeṣarahito 'pi jagato mūlam ity avagatatvād asty eva /
analyzed: tathā api sarva viśeṣa rahitaḥ u pi jagataḥ mūlam iti avagata tvāt asti eva
translated: Nevertheless, it exists because it is known to be the root of the world, although devoid of all distinctions.

original: kāryapravilāpanasyāstitvaniṣṭhatvāt /
analyzed: kārya pravilāpanasya astitva niṣṭha tvāt
translated: Because the existence of Brahman is the ultimate goal of the dissolution of effects.

original: tathā hīdaṃ kāryaṃ sūkṣmatāratamyapāramparyeṇānugamyamānaṃ sadbuddhiniṣṭhām evāvagamayati /
analyzed: tathā hi idam kāryam sūkṣma tāratamya pāramparyeṇa anugamyamānam sat buddhi niṣṭhām eva avagamayati
translated: For this effect, being followed in a series of increasingly subtle stages, makes one understand the ultimate state of true cognition.

original: yadāpi viṣayapravilāpanena pravilāpyamānā buddhis tadāpi sā satpratyayagarbhaiva vilīyate /
analyzed: yadā api viṣaya pravilāpanena pravilāpyamānā buddhiḥ tadā api sā sat pratyaya garbhā eva vilīyate
translated: Even when cognition, being dissolved by the dissolution of objects, dissolves, it dissolves only when pregnant with true cognition.

original: buddhir hi naḥ pramāṇaṃ sadasator yāthātmyāvagame /
analyzed: buddhiḥ hi naḥ pramāṇam sat asatoḥ yāthātmya avagame
translated: For our understanding is the means of knowing the real nature of the existent and the non-existent.

original: mūlaṃ cej jagato na syād asad anvitam evedaṃ kāryam asad ity evaṃ gṛhyeta /
analyzed: mūlam ced jagataḥ na syāt asat anvitam eva idam kāryam asat iti evam gṛhyeta
translated: And if it were not the root of the world, this effect would be apprehended as non-existent, associated with non-existence.

original: na tv etad asti /
analyzed: na tu etat asti
translated: But this is not so.

original: satyasad ity eva tu gṛhyate /
analyzed: satya sad iti eva tu gṛhyate
translated: Rather, it is apprehended as existent and existent.

original: yathā mṛdādikāryaṃ ghaṭādi mṛdādyanvitam /
analyzed: yathā mṛd ādi kāryam ghaṭa ādi mṛd ādi anvitam
translated: Just as the effect of clay, etc., such as a pot, is associated with clay, etc.

original: tasmāj jagato mūlam ātmāstīty evopalabdhavyaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt jagataḥ mūlam ātmā asti iti eva upalabdhavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the Self should be apprehended as the root of the world.

original: kasmāt /
analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

original: astīti bruvato 'stitvavādina āgamārthānusāriṇaḥ śraddadhānād anyatra nāstikavādini
analyzed: asti iti bruvataḥ stitva vādinaḥ āgama artha anusāriṇaḥ śraddadhānāt anyatra nāstika vādini
translated: For one who says it exists, who follows the meaning of the scriptures, who is faithful, except for one who advocates non-existence,

original: nāsti jagato mūlam ātmā niranvayam evedaṃ kāryam abhāvāntaṃ pravilīyata iti manyamāne viparītadarśini /
analyzed: na asti jagataḥ mūlam ātmā niranvayam eva idam kāryam abhāva antam pravilīyate iti manyamāne viparīta darśini
translated: who thinks that there is no root of the world, the Self, and that this effect dissolves into non-existence without remainder, who has a distorted view.

original: kathaṃ tad brahma tattvata upalabhyate /
analyzed: katham tat brahma tattvataḥ upalabhyate
translated: How is that Brahman to be apprehended in reality?

original: na kathañcanopalabhyata ity arthaḥ // // / / //🔽astīty evopalabdhavyas tattvabhāvena cobhayoḥ /
analyzed: na kathañcana upalabhyate iti arthaḥ  asti iti evā upalabdhavyaḥ tattva bhāvena ca ubhayoḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not apprehended in any way at all.🔽It exists should be apprehended, and the true nature of both should be seen.

original: astīty evopalabdhasya tattvabhāvaḥ prasīdati // // / / //
analyzed: asti iti eva upalabdhasya tattva bhāvaḥ prasīdati
translated: For one who apprehends it exists, the true nature becomes clear.

original: tasmād apohyāsadvādipakṣam āsuram astīty evātmopalabdhavyaḥ satkāryabuddhyādyupādhibhiḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt apohya asat vādi pakṣam āsuram asti iti eva ātmā upalabdhavyaḥ satkārya buddhi ādi upādhibhiḥ
translated: Therefore, the Self should be known as existing, by means of the limiting adjuncts such as the intellect, etc., which are the effects of the existent.

original: yadā tu tadrahito 'vikriya ātmā kāryaṃ ca kāraṇavyatirekeṇa nāsti vācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttikety eva satyam ChU / / iti śruteḥ
analyzed: yadā tu tad rahitaḥ vikriyaḥ ātmā kāryam ca kāraṇa vyatirekeṇa na asti vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam mṛttikā iti eva satyam chu iti śruteḥ
translated: But when the Self, free from those (adjuncts), is changeless, and the effect does not exist apart from the cause, and modification is mere verbal expression, and the name is only clay, as stated in the Vedic text only clay is true,

original: tadā tasya nirupādhikasyāliṅgasya sadasadādipratyayaviṣayatvavarjitasyātmanas tattvabhāvo bhavati /
analyzed: tadā tasya nirupādhikasya aliṅgasya sat asat ādi pratyaya viṣaya tva varjitasya ātmanaḥ tattva bhāvaḥ bhavati
translated: then there is the true nature of that Self, which is free from limiting adjuncts, which is without distinguishing marks, and which is devoid of being the object of the notions of existence, non-existence, etc.

original: tena ca rūpeṇātmopalabdhavya ity anuvartate /
analyzed: tena ca rūpeṇa ātmā upalabdhavyaḥ iti anuvartate
translated: And in that form, the Self is to be known. This is continued.

original: tatrāpy ubhayoḥ sopādhikanirupādhikayor astitvatattvabhāvayoḥ nirdhāraṇārthā ṣaṣṭhī pūrvam astīty evopalabdhasyātmanaḥ satkāryopādhikṛtāstitvapratyayenopalabdhasyety 🔽arthaḥ /
analyzed: tatra api ubhayoḥ sopādhika nirupādhikayoḥ astitva tattva bhāvayoḥ nirdhāraṇa arthā ṣaṣṭhī pūrvam asti iti eva upalabdhasya ātmanaḥ satkārya upādhi kṛta astitva pratyayena upalabdhasya iti  / arthaḥ
translated: There also, the genitive ending in tat-tattva-bhāvaḥ has the sense of determination between the two kinds of existence, that with limiting adjuncts and that without limiting adjuncts, and the true nature. The meaning is: of the Self, which was previously known as existing, which was known by the notion of existence produced by the limiting adjuncts such as the effect of the existent.

original: paścāt pratyastamitasarvopādhirūpa ātmanas tattvabhāvo viditāviditābhyāmanyo 'dvayasvabhāvo neti neti asthūlam anaṇv ahrasvam BĀU / /
analyzed: paścāt pratyasta mita sarva upādhi rūpaḥ ātmanaḥ tattva bhāvaḥ vidita aviditābhyām anyaḥ dvaya svabhāvaḥ na iti na iti a sthūlam an aṇu a hrasvam
translated: Later, the true nature of the Self, whose form has completely disappeared, is different from what is known and unknown, is of the nature of non-duality, is neither this nor that, is not gross, not atomic, not short, not long, not of variegated color, not dark, not sweet, not bitter, not cool, not hot, not empty, not non-empty, not true, not false, not day, not night, not past, not future, not present, not mind, not understanding, not consciousness, not sense, not non-sense, not existent, not non-existent, not bound, not liberated, not all, not not all, not one, not many, not true, not false, not this, not that, not both, not not both, not a substance, not a quality, not an action, not an attribute, not a universal, not an individual, not a substance, not a quality, not an action, not an attribute, not a universal, not an individual, not a substance, not a quality, not an action, not an attribute, not a universal, not an individual, not a substance, not a quality, not an action, not an attribute, not a universal, not an individual, not a substance, not a quality, not

original: adṛśye 'nātmye 'nirukte 'nilayane TaittU / /
analyzed: adṛśye nātmye nirukte nilayane tait tu
translated: In the unseen, non-self, unspecified, and unfixed, they are indeed.

original: ity ādi śrutinirdiṣṭaḥ prasīdatyabhimukhībhavati /
analyzed: iti ādi śruti nirdiṣṭaḥ prasīdati abhimukhībhavati
translated: Thus, indicated by the Upanishad, he becomes pleased, becomes favorably inclined.

original: ātmaprakāśanāya pūrvam astīty upalabdhavata ity etat // // / / //
analyzed: ātma prakāśanāya pūrvam asti iti upalabdhavataḥ iti etat
translated: For the manifestation of the Self, it is said that of one who has been known to exist...

original: yadā sarve pramucyante kāmā ye 'sya hṛdi śritāḥ /
analyzed: yadā sarve pramucyante kāmāḥ ye sya hṛdi śritāḥ
translated: When all the desires that are in his heart are released,

original: atha martyo 'mṛto bhavaty atra brahma samaśnute // // / / //
analyzed: atha martyaḥ mṛtaḥ bhavati atra brahma samaśnute
translated: then a mortal becomes immortal, and here he attains Brahman.

original: evaṃ paramārthātmadarśino yadā yasmin kāle sarve kāmāḥ kāmayitavyasyānyasyābhāvāt /🔽pramucyante /
analyzed: evam paramārtha ātma darśinaḥ yadā yasmin kāle sarve kāmāḥ kāmayitavyasya anyasya abhāvāt  pramucyante
translated: Thus, when all the desires of one who has seen the Self as the supreme truth are released, at that time, because there is nothing else to be desired,🔽they are released.

original: viśīryante /
analyzed: viśīryante
translated: They are scattered.

original: ye 'sya prāk pratibodhād viduṣo hṛdi buddhau śritā āśritāḥ /
analyzed: ye sya prāk pratibodhāt viduṣaḥ hṛdi buddhau śritāḥ āśritāḥ
translated: Those that were previously in the heart, in the intellect, of the wise person before awakening, to which he was attached,

original: buddhir hi kāmānām āśrayo nātmā kāmaḥ saṅkalpaḥ BĀU / /
analyzed: buddhiḥ hi kāmānām āśrayaḥ na ātmā kāmaḥ saṅkalpaḥ
translated: because the intellect is the abode of desires, not the Self. Desire is resolution, as stated in another Upanishad.

original: ity ādiśrutyantarāc ca /
analyzed: iti ādi śruti antarāt ca
translated: And because of this and other Upanishad passages.

original: atha tadā martyaḥ prāk prabodhād āsīt sa prabodhottarakālam avidyākāmakarmalakṣaṇasya mṛtyor vināśād amṛto bhavati /
analyzed: atha tadā martyaḥ prāk prabodhāt āsīt sa prabodha uttara kālam avidyā kāma karma lakṣaṇasya mṛtyoḥ vināśāt amṛtaḥ bhavati
translated: Then at that time, a mortal who existed before awakening, becomes immortal after awakening, due to the destruction of death characterized by ignorance, desire, and action.

original: gamanaprayojakasya mṛtyor vinaśād gamanānupapatter atrehaiva pradipanirvāṇavatsarvabandhanopaśamād brahma samaśnute brahmaiva bhavatīty arthaḥ
analyzed: gamana prayojakasya mṛtyoḥ vinaśāt gamana anupapatteḥ atra iha eva pradipa nirvāṇa vat sarva bandhana upaśamāt brahma samaśnute brahmā eva bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Since death, which is the cause of going, is destroyed, there is no possibility of going. Therefore, here itself, like the extinction of a lamp, he attains Brahman by the cessation of all bonds. The meaning is: he becomes Brahman itself.

original: yadā sarve prabhidyante hṛdayasyeha granthayaḥ /
analyzed: yadā sarve prabhidyante hṛdayasya iha granthayaḥ
translated: When all the knots of the heart are broken here,

original: atha martyo 'mṛto bhavaty etāvad dhy anuśāsanam // // / / //
analyzed: atha martyaḥ mṛtaḥ bhavati etāvat hi anuśāsanam
translated: then a mortal becomes immortal. This is the extent of the instruction.

original: kadā punaḥ kāmānāṃ mūlato vināśa ity ucyate yadā sarve prabhidyante bhedam upayānti
analyzed: kadā punar kāmānām mūlataḥ vināśaḥ iti ucyate yadā sarve prabhidyante bhedam upayānti
translated: When, indeed, is there a complete destruction of desires from the root? This is being said: When all the knots of the heart,🔽which are like knots, firm bonds,

original: vinaśyanti hṛdayasya buddher iha jīvata eva granthayo granthivad dṛḍhabandhanarūpā
analyzed: vinaśyanti hṛdayasya buddheḥ iha jīvataḥ eva granthayaḥ granthi vat dṛḍha bandhana rūpā
translated: which are based on ignorance, are broken, i.e., destroyed, even while one is alive.

original: avidyāpratyayā ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: avidyā pratyayāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: they are based on ignorance.

original: aham idaṃ śarīraṃ mamedaṃ dhanaṃ sukhī duḥkhī cāham ity evam ādilkṣaṇās tadviparītabrahmātmapratyayopajananād
analyzed: aham idam śarīram mama idam dhanam sukhī duḥkhī ca aham iti evam ādi lkṣaṇāḥ tad viparīta brahma ātma pratyaya upajananāt
translated: The characteristics such as I am this body, this is my wealth, I am happy or unhappy, etc., are destroyed by the arising of the knowledge of Brahman, which is the opposite of that.

original: brahmaivāham asmy asaṃsārīti vinaṣṭeṣv avidyāgranthiṣu tannimittāḥ kāmā mūlato vinaśyanti /
analyzed: brahma eva aham asmi asaṃsārī iti vinaṣṭeṣu avidyā granthiṣu tad nimittāḥ kāmāḥ mūlataḥ vinaśyanti
translated: When the knots of ignorance are destroyed, the desires based on that are completely destroyed from the root.

original: atha matryo 'mṛto bhavaty etāvad dhy etāvad evaitāvan mātraṃ nādhikam astīty āśaṅkā kartavyā /
analyzed: atha matryaḥ mṛtaḥ bhavati etāvat dhi etāvat eva etāvat mātram na adhikam asti iti āśaṅkā kartavyā
translated: Then he becomes immortal. For this much, this much only, this much is the measure, there is nothing more. Such a doubt should be entertained.

original: anuśāsanam anuśiṣṭir upadeśaḥ sarvavedāntānām iti vākyaśeṣaḥ // // / / //
analyzed: anuśāsanam anuśiṣṭiḥ upadeśaḥ sarva vedāntānām iti vākyaśeṣaḥ
translated: The instruction is the teaching of all the Vedānta texts. The rest of the sentence is omitted.

original: śataṃ caikā ca hṛdayasya nāḍyas tāsāṃ mūrdhānam abhiniḥsṛtaikā /
analyzed: śatam ca ekā ca hṛdayasya nāḍyaḥ tāsām mūrdhānam abhiniḥsṛtā ekā
translated: There are a hundred and one channels of the heart. Of them, one goes out through the head.

original: tayordhvam āyann amṛtatvam eti viṣvaṅṅ anyā utkramaṇe bhavati // // / / //
analyzed: tayā ūrdhvam āyan amṛta tvam eti viṣvaṅ anyā utkramaṇe bhavati
translated: Going upwards through that, one attains immortality. The other goes all around in the process of departing.

original: nirastāśeṣaviśeṣavyāpibrahmātmapratipattyā prabhinnasamastāvidyādigranther jīvata eva brahmabhūtasya viduṣo na gatir vidyate atra brahma samaśnute
analyzed: nirasta aśeṣa viśeṣa vyāpi brahma ātma pratipattyā prabhinna samasta avidyā ādi grantheḥ jīvataḥ eva brahma bhūtasya viduṣaḥ na gatiḥ vidyate atra brahma samaśnute  /
translated: For the knower who has broken all the knots of ignorance etc. by the realization of the all-pervading Brahman as the Self, which has expelled all distinctions, and who has become Brahman even while living, there is no destination, because it is said here: He attains Brahman.

original: ity uktatvāt na tasya prāṇā utkāmanti brahmaiva san brahmāpyeti BĀU / /🔽iti śrutyantarāc ca /
analyzed: iti ukta tvāt na tasya prāṇāḥ utkāmanti brahma eva san brahma apyeti  iti śruti antarāt ca
translated: And because of another scriptural passage: Being Brahman itself, he goes to Brahman.

original: ye punar mandabrahmavido vidyāntaraśīlinaś ca brahmalokabhājo ye ca tadviparītāḥ saṃsārabhājaḥ /
analyzed: ye punar manda brahma vidaḥ vidyā antara śīlinaḥ ca brahma loka bhājaḥ ye ca tad viparītāḥ saṃsāra bhājaḥ
translated: Those who have weak knowledge of Brahman, who are devoted to other knowledge, who attain the world of Brahman, and those who are the opposite of them, who attain the world of Brahman,

original: teṣām eva gativiśeṣa ucyate prakṛtotkṛṣṭabrahmavidyāphalastutaye /
analyzed: teṣām eva gati viśeṣaḥ ucyate prakṛta utkṛṣṭa brahma vidyā phala stutaye
translated: For them alone, the difference in destination is stated for the praise of the fruit of the excellent knowledge of Brahman that is being discussed.

original: kiñ cānyad agnividyā pṛṣṭā pratyuktā ca /
analyzed: kim ca anyat agni vidyā pṛṣṭā pratyuktā ca
translated: And further, the knowledge of fire was asked and answered.

original: tasyāś ca phalaprāptiprakāro vaktavya iti mantrārambhaḥ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ ca phala prāpti prakāraḥ vaktavyaḥ iti mantra ārambhaḥ
translated: And the way of attaining its fruit should be stated, so the mantra begins.

original: tatra śataṃ ca śatasaṅkhyākā ekā ca suṣumnā nāma puruṣasya hṛdayād viniḥsṛtā nāḍyaḥ śirāḥ /
analyzed: tatra śatam ca śata saṅkhyākāḥ ekā ca suṣumnā nāma puruṣasya hṛdayāt viniḥsṛtāḥ nāḍyaḥ sirāḥ
translated: There, one hundred and one are the channels of the human body, called the susumna, which emerge from the heart.

original: tāsāṃ madhye mūrdhānaṃ bhittvābhiniḥsṛtā nirgatā ekā suṣumnā nāma /
analyzed: tāsām madhye mūrdhānam bhittvā abhiniḥsṛtā nirgatā ekā suṣumnā nāma
translated: Among them, one called susumna emerges and comes out, piercing the crown of the head.

original: tayāntakāle hṛdaya ātmānaṃ vaśīkṛtya yojayet /
analyzed: tayā antakāle hṛdaye ātmānam vaśīkṛtya yojayet
translated: By that, at the time of death, having controlled the self in the heart, one should unite with it.

original: tayā nāḍyor dhvam uparyāyan gacchann ādityadvāreṇāmṛtatvam amaraṇadharmatvam āpekṣikam ābhūtasamplavaṃ sthānam amṛtatvaṃ hi bhāṣyate ViP
analyzed: tayā nāḍyoḥ upari āyan gacchan āditya dvāreṇa amṛta tvam a maraṇa dharma tvam āpekṣikam ābhūtasamplavam sthānam amṛta tvam hi bhāṣyate vip
translated: By that, going upwards above the two channels, going by the door of the sun, one attains immortality, the state of having the quality of not dying, the state of immortality up to the dissolution of all elements, which is said to be immortality.

original: iti smṛteḥ brahmaṇā vā saha kālāntareṇa mukhyam amṛtatvam eti bhuktvā bhogān anupamān brahmalokagatān /
analyzed: iti smṛteḥ brahmaṇā vā saha kāla antareṇa mukhyam amṛta tvam eti bhuktvā bhogān anupamān brahma loka gatān
translated: By the smrti: Or he goes to the highest immortality along with Brahma after some time, having enjoyed incomparable pleasures in the world of Brahma.

original: viṣvaṅnānāvidhagatayo 'nyā nāḍya utkramaṇe bhavanti saṃsārapratipattyarthā eva bhavantīty arthāḥ // // / / //
analyzed: viṣvak nānāvidha gatayaḥ nyāḥ nāḍyaḥ utkramaṇe bhavanti saṃsāra pratipatti arthāḥ eva bhavanti iti arthāḥ
translated: The other channels with various kinds of paths become the means of attaining worldly existence for one who departs.

original: aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo 'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ hṛdaye saṃniviṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: aṅguṣṭha mātraḥ puruṣaḥ ntarātmā sadā janānām hṛdaye saṃniviṣṭaḥ
translated: The person of the size of a thumb, the inner self, is always present in the heart of people.

original: taṃ svāc charīrāt pravṛhen muñjād iveṣīkāṃ dhairyeṇa /
analyzed: tam svāt śarīrāt pravṛhet muñjāt iva iṣīkām dhairyeṇa
translated: One should extract him from one's own body, like a reed from a clump of reeds, with firmness.

original: taṃ vidyāc chukram amṛtaṃ taṃ vidyāc chukram amṛtam iti // // / / //
analyzed: tam vidyāt śukram amṛtam tam vidyāt śukram amṛtam iti
translated: One should know him as the pure, immortal one. One should know him as the pure, immortal one.

original: idānīṃ sarvavallyarthopasaṃhārārtham āha aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo 'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ sambandhini hṛdaye san niviṣṭo yathā vyākhyātaḥ /
analyzed: idānīm sarvavallī artha upasaṃhāra artham āha aṅguṣṭha mātraḥ puruṣaḥ ntarātmā sadā janānām sambandhini hṛdaye san niviṣṭaḥ yathā vyākhyātaḥ
translated: Now, in order to conclude the meaning of all the Upaniṣads, it is said: The person of the size of a thumb, the inner self, is always present in the heart related to people, as explained.

original: taṃ svādātmīyāc charīrāt pravṛhed udyacchen niṣkarṣet pṛthak kuryād ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tam svāt ātmīyāt śarīrāt pravṛhet udyacchet niṣkarṣet pṛthak kuryāt iti arthaḥ
translated: One should extract him from one's own body, the meaning is: one should lift him up, extract him, make him separate.

original: kim ivety ucyate muñjādiveṣīkāmantasthāṃ dhairyeṇāpramādena /
analyzed: kim iva iti ucyate muñja ādi veṣīkām antasthām dhairyeṇa apramādena
translated: What is he like? It is said: like a reed from a clump of reeds, with firmness, with care.

original: taṃ śarīrān niṣkṛṣṭaṃ cinmātraṃ vidyādvijānīyāc chukraṃ śuddham amṛtaṃ yathoktaṃ brahmeti /
analyzed: tam śarīrāt niṣkṛṣṭam cit mātram vidyāt vijānīyāt śukram śuddham amṛtam yathā uktam brahma iti
translated: One should know that pure, immortal consciousness extracted from the body as the pure, immortal one, as explained as Brahman.

original: dvir vacanam upaniṣat parisamāpty artham iti śabdaś ca // // / / //
analyzed: dvis vacanam upaniṣad parisamāptī artham iti śabdaḥ ca
translated: The repetition is for the completion of the Upaniṣad. The word iti (thus) is used to indicate the end of the text.

original: mṛtyuproktāṃ naciketo 'tha labdhvā vidyām etāṃ yogavidhiṃ ca kṛtsnam /
analyzed: mṛtyu proktām labdhvā vidyām etām yoga vidhim ca kṛtsnam
translated: Then Naciketas, having obtained this knowledge and the entire method of yoga, as declared by Death,

original: brahmaprāpto virajo 'bhūd vimṛtyur anyo 'py evaṃ yo vid adhyātmam eva // // / / //
analyzed: brahma prāptaḥ virajaḥ bhūt vimṛtyuḥ evam yaḥ vid adhyātmam eva
translated: Having attained Brahman, he became free from passion, free from death. Another also who knows thus the Self, indeed, becomes free from passion, free from death.

original: vidyāstutyartho 'yam ākhyāyikārthopasaṃhāro 'dhunocyate mṛtyuproktām etāṃ yathoktāṃ brahmavidyāṃ yogavidhiṃ ca kṛtsnaṃ samastaṃ sopakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: vidyā stuti arthaḥ yam ākhyāyikā artha upasaṃhāraḥ dhunā ucyate mṛtyu proktām etām yathā uktām brahma vidyām yoga vidhim ca kṛtsnam samastam sa upakaraṇam
translated: The conclusion of the meaning of the story, which is for the praise of knowledge, is now being stated. He who has obtained, has attained, this Brahman-knowledge described by Death, and the entire Yoga method along with its requisites,

original: saphalam ity etat /
analyzed: saphalam iti etat
translated: together with its fruits. This is the meaning.

original: naciketo 'tha varapradānān mṛtyor labdhvā prāpyety arthaḥ /
analyzed: vara pradānāt mṛtyoḥ labdhvā prāpya iti arthaḥ
translated: Then Naciketas, having obtained, having attained, by the bestowal of boons from Death, this is the meaning.

original: kim / brahma prāpto 'bhūn mukto 'bhavad ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kim brahma prāptaḥ bhūt muktaḥ bhavat iti arthaḥ
translated: What? He became one who has attained Brahman, he became liberated, is the meaning.

original: katham / vidyāprāptyā virajo vigatadharmādharmo vimṛtyur vigatakāmāvidyaś ca san pūrvam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: katham vidyā prāptyā virajaḥ vigata dharma adharmaḥ vimṛtyuḥ vigata kāma avidyaḥ ca san pūrvam iti arthaḥ
translated: How? By the attainment of knowledge, he became free from passion, free from dharma and adharma, free from death, free from desire and ignorance, and was as before, is the meaning.

original: na kevalaṃ naciketā evānyo 'pi ya evaṃ naciketovad ātmavid adhyātmam eva nirupacaritaṃ pratyak svarūpaṃ prāpya tattvam evety abhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: na kevalam naciketāḥ eva anyaḥ pi yaḥ evam naciketaḥ vat ātma vid adhyātmam eva nirupacaritam pratyak svarūpam prāpya tattvam eva iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Not only Naciketas, but another also who knows the Self thus, like Naciketas, having attained the Self alone, the unmodified, the inward, the own-nature, the reality alone, is the intention.

original: nānyad rūpam apratyag rūpam /
analyzed: na anyat rūpam a pratyak rūpam
translated: Not any other form, not the outward form.

original: tad evam adhyātmam evam uktaprakāreṇa veda vijānātīty evaṃvit so 'pi virajāḥ san brahma prāpya vimṛtyur bhavatīti vākyaśeṣaḥ // // / /🔽saha nāv avatu /
analyzed: tat evam adhyātmam evam ukta prakāreṇa veda vijānāti iti evaṃvid saḥ u pi virajāḥ san brahma prāpya vimṛtyuḥ bhavati iti vākya śeṣaḥ  / saha nau avatu
translated: Thus, one who knows in this way, i.e., who knows the Self in the manner described, he too, being free from impurity, attains Brahman and becomes immortal. This is the remainder of the sentence.🔽May it protect us both together.

original: saha nau bhunaktu /
analyzed: saha nau bhunaktu
translated: May it enjoy us both together.

original: saha vīryaṃ karavāvahai //
analyzed: saha vīryam karavāvahai
translated: May we perform heroic deeds together.

original: tejasvi nāvadhītam astu mā vidviṣāvahai // // / / //
analyzed: tejasvi nau adhītam astu mā vidviṣāvahai
translated: May our brilliance be undiminished. May we not hate each other.

original: oṃ śāntiḥ śāntiḥ śāntiḥ //
analyzed: om śāntiḥ śāntiḥ śāntiḥ
translated: Om. Peace. Peace. Peace.

original: iti kaṭhopaniṣadi dvitīyādhyāye tṛtīyā vallī //🔽śiṣyācāryayoḥ pramādakṛtānyāyena vidyāgrahaṇapratipādananimittadoṣapraśamanārtheyaṃ śāntir ucyate saha nāv āvām avatu pālayatu vidyāsvarūpaprakāśanena
analyzed: iti kaṭhopaniṣadi dvitīya adhyāye tṛtīyā vallī  śiṣya ācāryayoḥ pramāda kṛta anyāyena vidyā grahaṇa pratipādana nimitta doṣa praśamana arthā iyam śāntiḥ ucyate saha nau āvām avatu pālayatu vidyā sva rūpa prakāśanena
translated: Thus ends the third Valli of the second chapter in the Katha Upanishad.

original: kaḥ / sa eva parameśvara upaniṣat prakāśitaḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ saḥ eva parameśvara upaniṣad prakāśitaḥ
translated: This peace is stated for the purpose of removing the faults arising from the disciple and the teacher's improper acquisition and teaching of knowledge due to negligence. May that very same Supreme Lord, who is revealed in the Upanishads, protect us both together.

original: kiñ ca saha nau bhunaktu tatphalaprakāśanena nau pālayatu /
analyzed: kim ca saha nau bhunaktu tad phala prakāśanena nau pālayatu
translated: And may He enjoy us both together by revealing its fruits, and protect us both.

original: sahaivāvāṃ vidyākṛtaṃ vīryaṃ sāmathryaṃ karavāvahai niṣpādayāvahai /
analyzed: saha eva āvām vidyā kṛtam vīryam sāmathryam karavāvahai niṣpādayāvahai
translated: Together, we shall perform heroic deeds, i.e., accomplish them, by means of knowledge.

original: kiñ ca tejasvi nau tejasvi naurāvayor yad adhītaṃ tat svadhītam astu /
analyzed: kim ca tejasvi nau tejasvi nau rāvayoḥ yat adhītam tat su adhītam astu
translated: And, tejasvi, may the learning of both of us, na, be well-learned.

original: athavā tejasvi nāvāvābhyāṃ yad adhītaṃ tad atīva tejasvi vīryavad astv ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: athavā tejasvi nāvā āvābhyām yat adhītam tat atīva tejasvi vīryavat astu iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning is: may the learning of both of us, tejasvi, be extremely brilliant and vigorous.

original: mā vidviṣāvahai śiṣyācāryāv anyonyaṃ pramādakṛtānyāyādhyayanādhyāpanadoṣanimittaṃ dveṣaṃ mā karavāvahai ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: mā vidviṣāvahai śiṣya ācāryau anyonyam pramāda kṛta anyāya adhyayana adhyāpana doṣa nimittam dveṣam mā karavāvahai iti arthaḥ
translated: May we not hate each other, the disciple and the teacher, meaning we should not have mutual hatred caused by the faults of studying and teaching due to negligence.

original: śāntiḥ śāntiḥ śāntir iti trir vacanaṃ sarvadoṣopaśamanārtham ity om iti // // / / //
analyzed: śāntiḥ śāntiḥ śāntiḥ iti tris vacanam sarva doṣa upaśamana artham iti om iti
translated: The statement peace, peace, peace three times is for the purpose of pacifying all faults. Thus, Om.

original: iti śrīmat paramahaṃsaparivrājakācāryasya śrī govindabhagavatpūjyapādaśiṣyasya śrī śaṅkarabhagavataḥ kṛtau kāṭhakopaniṣadbhāṣyaṃ samāptam //
analyzed: iti śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācāryasya śrī govinda bhagavat pūjya pāda śiṣyasya śrī śaṅkara bhagavataḥ kṛtau kāṭhaka upaniṣad bhāṣyam samāptam
translated: Thus ends the commentary on the Katha Upanishad composed by the revered Shankara, the disciple of the revered Govindabhagavatpada, the great sage and preceptor of the order of mendicants following the great path.
